Legal_Issue: Interpretation and application of residency requirement under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent from Canada for 521 days during the four-year period preceding the application
Remedy_Requested: Overturn of Citizenship Judge's decision and grant of citizenship
Court_Ruling: The Citizenship Judge's decision was reasonable and based on the evidence
Defendant_Behavior: Extended absences from Canada; employment abroad while maintaining some family ties in Canada
Grounds_for_Claim: Misinterpretation of the residency test and failure to consider relevant evidence
Assessment_Factor: Koo factors: employment, family ties, intention to return, centralization of life in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from a Citizenship Judge’s decision to the Federal Court
Evidence_Used: Duration of absences, nature of employment abroad, family connections in Canada, intent to reside in Canada
Application_Basis: Accumulation of at least three years of physical residence in Canada within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Applicant's travel history, employment records, familial relationships, statements of intent
Governing_Rule: Koo factors for assessing residency under s. 5(1)(c)
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to demonstrate that life was centralized in Canada despite partial physical presence
Cause_Description: Rasaei's application for Canadian citizenship was denied due to non-compliance with residency requirements
Evidence_Handling: The Citizenship Judge considered all relevant evidence including employment and family ties
Residency_Compliance: Not met – 521 days of absence exceeds allowable limit without sufficient justification under Koo factors
Evidence_Assessment: Conducted using the Koo analytical framework; found no error in weighing of factors
Decision_Rationale: The Citizenship Judge reasonably concluded that the applicant did not centralize his life in Canada during the relevant period
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
